title: NYPD’s Top Uniformed Officer Leaves for City Hall
sub_head: Departure of NYPD Chief of Department Terence Monahan is the latest leadership change at the force
body:
The New York Police Department’s top uniformed officer is leaving the department after nearly four decades to take a job in City Hall, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Thursday.
Chief of Department Terence Monahan is the latest high-ranking official to leave his job at the NYPD as the department undergoes a series of changes under the leadership of Commissioner Dermot Shea, who took office in January of last year.
Mr. Monahan, who has been at the NYPD for 39 years, said Thursday that he had been looking to retire and take a job in the private sector when Mr. de Blasio approached him about coming to City Hall as a senior adviser.
He will work with Lorraine Grillo, who was appointed this week as the city’s Covid-19 recovery czar, and focus on public safety, he said.
Mr. Monahan, who is 59, said his years working with local business-improvement districts and nonprofit organizations, and his experience in creating the NYPD’s neighborhood-policing initiative will guide him in his new role.
